titleStmt.title: High aminopeptidase A activity contributes to blood pressure control in ob/ob mice by AT 2 receptor-dependent mechanism

analytic.title: High aminopeptidase A activity contributes to blood pressure control in ob/ob mice by AT 2 receptor-dependent mechanism

biblStruct.note: Submitted 11 July 2016; accepted in final form 6 December 2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Obesity is assumed to be a major cause of human essential hypertension; however, the mechanisms responsible for weight-related increase in blood pressure (BP) are not fully understood.
The prevalence of hypertension induced by obesity has grown over the years, and the role of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) in this process continues to be elucidated.
In this scenario, the ob/ob mice are a genetic obesity model generally used for metabolic disorder studies.
These mice are normotensive even though they present several metabolic conditions that predispose them to hypertension.

Although the normotensive trait in these mice is associated with the poor activation of sympathetic nervous system by the lack of leptin, we demonstrated that ob/ob mice present massively increased aminopeptidase A (APA) activity in the circulation.
APA enzyme metabolizes angiotensin (ANG) II into ANG III, a peptide associated with intrarenal angiotensin type 2 (AT2) receptor activation and induction of natriuresis.
In these mice, we found increased ANG-III levels in the circulation, high AT2 receptor expression in the kidney, and enhanced natriuresis.
AT2 receptor blocking and APA inhibition increased BP, suggesting the ANG III-AT2 receptor axis as a complementary BP control mechanism.
Circulating APA activity was significantly reduced by weight loss independently of leptin, indicating the role of fat tissue in APA production.
Therefore, in this study we provide new data supporting the role of APA in BP control in ob/ob mouse strain.
These findings improve our comprehension about obesity-related hypertension and suggest new tools for its treatment.
In this study, we reported an increased angiotensin III generation in the circulation of ob/ob mice caused by a high aminopeptidase A activity.

These findings are associated with an increased natriuresis found in these mice and support the role of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system as additional mechanism regulating blood pressure in this genetic obese strain.

aminopeptidase A; hypertension; obesity; renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system; ob/ob mice HYPERTENSION IS A SERIOUS health problem and a major risk factor for coronary heart and cerebrovascular disease (40).

Increased blood pressure (BP) is estimated to cause 7.5 million deaths per year worldwide (41,42) and is also associated with heart failure, renal impairment, and damage to peripheral and retinal blood vessels (9, 40 -42).
In recent decades, the prevalence of hypertension has increased along with obesity cases, where excess of weight gain was associated with BP increase (8,24).
Obesity and hypertension are linked to the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), a major regulator of BP, which controls body fluid and electrolyte homeostasis (13,38).
RAAS is activated in animals treated by high-fat diet (HFD), where increased angiotensin (ANG) II levels and high BP are observed (4,12).
RAAS inhibitors can normalize high BP caused by obesity in experimental models (5), as well as in humans (20).
On the other hand, secondary effects of RAAS downregulation by pharmacological inhibition (32) or genetic disruption (22) include body weight and fat tissue loss.
The connection between RAAS and metabolism has narrowed over the years with fat tissue as a major factor for hypertension development (43).
In this scenario, aminopeptidase A (APA) is a membrane-bound and soluble enzyme component of RAAS (10,16) that cleaves the NH 2 -terminal aspartate of ANG II to generate ANG III (30,39).
In past years, several studies related APA and hypertension (3,14,21,29,33).
Recently, Kemp et al. (25) demonstrated that intrarenal ANG III, but not ANG II or ANG-(1-7), induces natriuresis via activation of angiotensin type 2 (AT 2 ) receptors.
These data highlight the importance of APA in natriuresis by regulating the generation of ANG III from ANG II.
We investigated the regulation of APA expression and activity in the genetically obese strain ob/ob mouse.

As already shown in previous studies, ob/ob mice do not develop hypertension, despite several metabolic conditions favoring BP increase such as severe obesity (19,26), dyslipidemia, hyperinsulinemia, hyperglycemia, and insulin resistance (15,28).

Although the poor sympathetic nervous system (SNS) activation explains part of the normotensive trait observed in these animals (18), here we demonstrated that ob/ob mice present significantly increased APA activity in the blood, which would be a possible mechanism counteracting the elevation of ANG II in severe obesity (4,12).
However, the regulation of APA activity is not entirely understood.
In this study, we demonstrated that APA activity in ob/ob mice is highly increased when compared with their lean control.
Body weight changes were able to regulate APA activity in the circulation, which suggests the role of fat tissue in this process.
As a result of high APA activity, ANG III levels were elevated in the circulation of ob/ob mice, together with enhanced natriuresis and AT 2 receptor expression in kidney.
AT 2 receptor blocking and APA inhibition increased BP, indicating their role in BP control.

Therefore, we propose that increased APA activity in ob/ob mice could be an additional mechanism regulating BP in these obese mice, in which ANG III-AT 2 receptor axis activation promotes increased sodium excretion.
Animals.
We used adult 16-wk-old male ob/ob, ob/ϩ wild-type (WT) C57Bl/6 mice purchased from CEDEME, the animal house of Universidade Federal de São Paulo (UNIFESP).
The apolipoprotein E (apoE Ϫ/Ϫ )-deficient mice were purchased from the Jackson Laboratory.
Animals were maintained on 12-h:12-h light-dark cycle at 22°C with free access to standard chow and water.
The experimental protocols and procedures were submitted and approved by the local Institutional Ethical Committee (0205/2010).
The protocols and pro-cedures are in accordance with the National Institutes of Health guide for the care and use of laboratory animals.
Measurement of APA activity.
Mouse serum was collected and stored at Ϫ80°C until use.

Total tissue was collected and immediately homogenized in cold buffer A, consisting of 50 mM Tris•HCl and 4 mM CaCl2; pH 7.4, and centrifuged at 10,000 g for 15 min at 4°C; the supernatant was stored at Ϫ80°C.
APA activity assessment was performed by fluorescence measurement (ex ϭ 340 nm and em ϭ 410 nm) followed by hydrolysis of specific substrate glutamyl ␤-naphthylamide (Glu-␤NA, Bachem).
Basically, an aliquot of homogenized tissue or mouse serum was incubated with buffer A and 20 M of Glu-␤NA substrate at 37°C under agitation for 20 min.
The fluorescence was detected and analyzed by spectrofluorometer (Spec-traMax Gemini XS, Molecular Devices).
The fluorescence parameter was set as arbitrary fluorescence units.
Amastatin was used as inhibitor for APA activity at 10 M.
Real-time PCR.
Total RNA (2 g) was reverse-transcribed using M-MLV (Invitrogen) to cDNA as suggested by the manufacturer.
The reaction product was amplified by real-time PCR using the SYBR Green reaction kit (Thermo Scientific).
mRNA was quantified as relative value compared with the ␤-actin housekeeping gene.

Primers used for real-time PCR were as follows: murine APA forward primer 5=-ACAGTGTCTATCGGCTGAC-3= and reverse primer 5=-TCCTG-GCATCTGTTGGTTC-3=; murine ␤-actin forward primer 5=-GAAC-CCTAAGGCCAACCGTGAA-3= and reverse primer 5=-GACCA-GAGGCATACAGGGACAAC-3=; murine AT 1 receptor forward In vitro and in vivo leptin treatment.
For in vitro actions of leptin in APA activity, sera from ob/ob and ob/ϩ mice were incubated with 200 ng/ml of leptin (R&D Systems) or diluent (control group) for 1 h.
For acute leptin treatment in vivo, ob/ob mice were injected intravenously with leptin (1 mg/kg) or saline.
After 1 h, the serum was collected for analysis.
For chronic leptin treatment, ob/ob mice were treated daily with intraperitoneal leptin injections (1 mg/kg) or saline for 21 days.
The mice were weighed before and after the treatment to verify the effective weight loss.
After the treatment, the animals were euthanized and the sera and tissues were collected for further analysis.
Food restriction treatment.
Ob/ob mice were put in food restriction treatment or free food access (ad libitum) for 12 wk.
Each mouse was put in an individual cage and was weighted weekly.
For the first 3 wk mice from the restriction group received 30% less food.
After 3 wk the food restriction was set to 50% less food until 12 wk of treatment.
Food restriction calculation was based on average daily consumption for each mouse for 7 days before treatment.
After the treatment mice were euthanized for serum and tissue collection.
High-fat diet treatment.
Wild-type C57BL/6 mice 12-wk-old were fed ad libitum for 12 wk with control diet (10% kcal from fat) or HFD (60% kcal from fat), both commercial diets (Research Diets).
Each mouse was put in an individual cage and was weighted weekly.
After the treatment mice were euthanized for serum and tissue collection.
LC-MS/MS-based quantification of circulating angiotensin peptide levels.
Mice were anesthetized with isoflurane.
After full anesthesia effect, 500 l of blood were directly collected from the heart and put in an ice-cold, 1.5-ml tube containing the cocktail inhibitors.
Plasma was obtained after 2,000 g centrifugation for 10 min at 4°C and stored at Ϫ80°C until analysis.

Circulating angiotensin metabolites concentrations were determined by mass spectrometry using plasma samples collected in the presence of an inhibitor cocktail completely blocking angiotensin metabolism containing ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid, pepstatin A, p-hydroxymercuribenzoic acid, phenanthroline, serine proteases, and specific inhibitors for renin and aminopeptidases A and N to a final concentration of 5% vol/vol (Attoquant Diagnostics, Vienna, Austria).

Stabilized plasma (200 l) was spiked with stable isotope-labeled internal standards for each angiotensin metabolite, ANG I, ANG II, ANG-(1-7), ANG III, ANG IV, and ANG-(2-10) at a concentration of 200 pg/ml.

After C18-based solid-phase-extraction, samples were subjected to liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry/ mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) analysis by using a reversed-phase analytical column (Acquity UPLC C18, Waters) operating in line with a XEVO TQ-S triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (Waters) in multiple reaction monitoring mode.
Internal standards were used to correct for peptide recovery of the sample preparation procedure for each angiotensin metabolite in each individual sample.

Angiotensin concentrations were calculated considering the corresponding response factors determined in appropriate calibration curves, on condition that integrated signals exceeded a signal-to-noise ratio of 10.

The lower limit of quantification in picograms per milliliters of plasma for individual angiotensin metabolites were the following: ANG I ϭ 4, ANG II ϭ 3, ANG 1-7 ϭ 5.5, ANG III ϭ 3, ANG IV ϭ 2.8, and ANG 2-10 ϭ 4.
cGMP measurement.
For guanosine 3=,5=-cyclic monophosphate (cGMP) measurement, total mice kidney was homogenized and used as samples.
cGMP level was measured by a commercial kit (Cayman) with the whole procedure performed as specified by the manufacturer.
PD123319 and amastatin treatment.

Male ob/ob mice were injected intraperitoneally with saline (vehicle), 3 mg•kg Ϫ1 •day Ϫ1 of AT 2 receptor antagonist (PD123319, Abcam) or 3 mg•kg Ϫ1 •day Ϫ1 of APA inhibitor (Amastatin, Bachem) during 21 days.
BP was measured weekly, and at the end of the treatment, water consump-0.00E+00
Urine analysis and water consumption.
Mice were individualized and placed in metabolic cages for 24 h with ad libitum water and without food.
Urine was collected and the volume measured as well as water consumption for each animal.
After urine collection, sodium concentration was analyzed by an electrolyte analyzer (Roche AVL 9180), and the values were reported as milliequivalents per liter (mq/l).
Measurements of BP in conscious mice.
Male ob/ob mice were equipped with catheters in the femoral artery and vein by surgical procedure under chloral hydrate (400 mg/kg) anesthesia.
After a 48-h recovery period, the arterial catheter was connected to a pressure transducer (PowerLab, ADI Instruments) and mean arterial pressure was recorded under basal conditions.
The "tail cuff" method was used specifically for BP measurement in PD123319 and Amastatin treatments (PowerLab, ADI Instruments).
Statistical analysis.
Results were reported as means Ϯ SE.
Statistically significant differences in mean values were evaluated by independent Student t-tests when two groups were compared or ANOVA for more groups comparison.
A value of P Յ 0.05 was considered significant.
Ob/ob mice present higher APA activity in serum and kidney.
APA activity was quantified and a fivefold increase was observed in the serum of ob/ob mice when compared with that in control (Fig. 1A).
The specificity of the assay was demonstrated by blocking the activity with amastatin, an APA inhibitor (Fig. 1A).
Higher APA activity was observed in the kidney and lower activity in lung of ob/ob mice (Fig. 1B).
Similarly, APA mRNA expression was also higher in kidney and lower in lung (Fig. 1C).
Chronic leptin treatment reduces APA activity in ob/ob mice.
In this set of experiments we wanted to check whether the loss of leptin in ob/ob mice was directly involved in APA regulation.
Leptin was incubated with ob/ϩ and ob/ob mice serum in vitro, and no changes were observed in APA activity (Fig. 2A).
In addition, when leptin was injected acutely in vivo in ob/ob mice, no effect on APA activity was observed (Fig. 2B).
However, long-term leptin treatment reduced APA activity in the blood (Fig. 2C) but not in kidney (Fig. 2D).
As expected, chronic administration of leptin induced body weight loss in ob/ob mice (Fig. 2E).
Body weight changes modulate APA activity in mice.
To evaluate whether APA activity reduction after leptin treatment was due to leptin or weight loss, we submitted ob/ob mice to a food restriction (FR) treatment for 12 wk (Fig. 3A).
APA activity was decreased in animals after FR when compared with the free fed group (Fig. 3B).
Conversely, body weight gain in HFD-treated WT mice (Fig. 3C) increased APA activity in the circulation (Fig. 3D).
As indi- 3E).
Cholesterol does not regulate APA activity in apoE Ϫ/Ϫ mice.

To investigate whether high-cholesterol levels were responsible for increased APA activity observed in ob/ob mice, we analyzed the serum of apoE Ϫ/Ϫ mice, which displayed significantly increased levels of plasma cholesterol.
However, no changes were observed in circulating APA activity and body weight in these mice, suggesting that cholesterol levels do not alter APA activity (Table 1).
ANG III peptide is elevated in the circulation of ob/ob mice.
The concentration of angiotensins was quantified in the circulation of ob/ob and ob/ϩ mice by LC-MS/MS technique.
The levels of ANG I, II, IV, 1-7, and 2-10 were not different when compared with ob/ϩ control mice (Figs. 4, A-F).
However, in agreement to the higher APA activity in the circulation, we observed elevated levels of ANG III in the circulation of ob/ob mice (Fig. 4C).
Normotensive ob/ob mice present increased natriuresis.
Ob/ob mice presented the same BP values as their ob/ϩ controls (Fig. 5A).
Urine sodium excretion, urine volume, and water consumption were, however, increased in ob/ob mice (Figs. 5, B-D).
AT 2 receptor mRNA expression (Fig. 5F) and cGMP levels in the kidney were also significantly increased in ob/ob mice (Fig. 5G).
These findings suggest an augmented AT 2 receptor activation in the kidney by the cGMP signaling, leading to an increased natriuresis in these mice.
AT 2 receptor blockade and APA inhibition increase BP in ob/ob mice.
Ob/ob mice presented increased BP and elevated natriuresis after 3 wk of treatment with the AT 2 blocker PD123319 when compared with vehicle (Figs. 6, A and B).
Amastatin also increased BP in these mice after 3 wk of treatment (Fig. 6E).
These data confirm the role of AT 2 receptor and APA as active mechanisms regulating BP in ob/ob mice.
Obesity is a major cause of human essential hypertension, but the mechanisms responsible for weight-related increase in BP are not fully understood.
The prevalence of hypertension induced by obesity has grown over the years (8,24), and the role of RAAS in this process continues to be elucidated (43).
In this scenario, the ob/ob mice are a genetic model of obesity generally used for metabolic disorder studies.
Despite the several factors favoring a BP increase in these mice, they do not develop hypertension and are considered normotensive (26).
To better elucidate this apparent paradox, we investigated the APA enzyme and its regulation in this mouse obese strain.
Recent studies reported the activation of the SNS in hypertension-associated obesity in which body weight gain correlates to SNS activation in experimental models and human subjects (1,11,18).
Chronic leptin infusion causes sustained elevation in BP dependent on adrenergic receptor activation (6), exerting its effects on SNS through the melanocortin receptor 4 (7,34,37).
Thus the poor SNS activation caused by the lack of leptin could explain part of the ob/ob mice normotensive trait.
However, RAAS components also play an important role in BP regulation.
Our group has already described a reduced activity of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) in the circulation of ob/ob mice (19), which also led to reduced efficiency of the ACE inhibitor enalapril.
Despite the low ACE activity, ANG I metabolism in ob/ob mice serum generated not only ANG II but also other metabolites lacking the NH 2terminal amino acids (data not shown).
A detailed analysis of these metabolites revealed a high-circulating APA activity in ob/ob mice, as well as a higher activity and gene expression in the kidney.
As already reported, exogenous administration of leptin can modulate ACE activity (19).
Here we show that leptin was unable to modulate APA activity in vitro or acutely in vivo; however, a long-term leptin treatment reduced its activity.
Chronic leptin treatment is known to reverse the phenotype found in ob/ob mice, including body weight and sterility (31).
HIGH AMINOPEPTIDASE A ACTIVITY IN OB/OB MICE However, it remained unclear whether after leptin treatment, APA activity reduction was caused directly or indirectly by weight loss.
To answer this question, mice were submitted to a FR regimen for 12 wk, which resulted in decreased APA activity, independently of leptin.
Conversely, HFD increased APA activity proportionally with body weight gain.
Since body weight changes modulate several molecules related to metabolism, we decided to understand their correlation to APA activity.
Cholesterol has been described as modulator of APA activity in vitro (27); however, we failed to support these findings.
In our experiments, the apoE Ϫ/Ϫ mice, an atherosclerosis model, which presents elevated cholesterol levels in the circulation, displayed no changes in APA activity.
Accordingly, cholesterol had no effect in vitro on APA activity either (data not shown).
Although we found that cholesterol does not regulate APA activity, we hypothesized that fat tissue could be involved.
RAAS is described as functional in fat tissue and its participation is essential in hypertension development (43).
Thus we believe that fat loss after FR treatment is strongly associated to APA activity reduction in the circulation of ob/ob mice.
In the same way, body weight gain increased APA activity.
On the basis of these findings, we suggest that adipocytes could be a major source of circulating APA.
Nevertheless, it will require further investigations to better understand the mechanisms behind APA regulation.
In agreement with high APA activity, elevated levels of ANG III were also detected in the circulation of ob/ob mice.
Recently, it has been shown that intrarenal ANG III, but not ANG II or ANG (1-7), induces natriuresis via activation of AT 2 receptors in rats in a cGMP-dependent mechanism (25).
The authors suggested increasing ANG III levels generated by inhibition of aminopeptidase N (APN) could be a potential therapeutic approach to hypertension treatment.

In accordance with these findings, ob/ob mice presented increased renal expression of AT 2 receptor, increased cGMP levels in the kidney, and elevated natriuresis when compared with their lean controls.

AT 2 receptor blockade confirmed its role in BP regulation and promoted BP increase with low-sodium excretion, suggesting this pathway as an alternative mechanism for 36), indicating that at least in ob/ob mice, APA and AT 2 receptor represent an important role in BP regulation.
Therefore, we suggest that increased APA activity in the circulation, and in the kidney, could activate the ANG III-AT 2 receptor axis and induce Na ϩ output increase in this obese mouse strain.
However, there are still some pieces missing from this puzzle.
Studies with several populations worldwide have shown that excess of weight gain is predictable of future hypertension.
In fact, there seems to be an almost linear correlation between body mass index and BP (17).
However, this fact does not hold entirely true for ob/ob mice.
The lack of leptin signaling and SNS activation retains the normotensive trait observed in these animals, which seems to be also true for humans (35).
On the other hand, RAAS is a classical system known for BP control and APA is already described as a potential factor regulating BP increase in rodents.
In this sense, APA and candesartan, an AT 1 receptor blocker, produced the same effect on systolic BP when administrated intravenously in spontaneously hypertensive rats (21).
Also, APA knockout mice develop hypertension spontaneously and are more sensitive to ANG-II infusion (29).

Besides its effect on ANG II-AT 1 receptor axis, we suggest that the high-APA activity in ob/ob mice activates the ANG III-AT 2 receptor axis and induces increased natriuresis, as pointed out by our results.
Therefore, we propose that the massively increased APA activity found in ob/ob mice, together with their impaired SNS activation, are the main reason for the regular BP observed in this mouse strain.
In summary, this study presents new data regarding the APA regulation and its role on BP control.

These findings highlight the action of circulating APA in ANG-II metabolism and ANG-III generation in ob/ob mice, proposing an enhanced natriuresis as a complementary mechanism for BP control in these obese mice.
These data advance our understanding of RAAS and its complexity and suggest possible new tools for hypertension treatment.
Fig. 4. Angiotensins measurement by liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry/mass spectrometry in plasma of ob/ϩ and ob/ob mice.
Angiotensin I (A), angiotensin II (B), angiotensin III (C), angiotensin IV (D), angiotensin 1-7 (E), and angiotensin 2-10 (F) levels in plasma of ob/ϩ and ob/ob mice are shown.
Data are expressed as means Ϯ SE of picograms per milliliter.
**P Ͻ 0.01 ob/ob vs. ob/ϩ group; ns, not significant; ob/ϩ, n ϭ 4; ob/ob, n ϭ 4.

We are grateful to our laboratory technicians Emanoel Barreto and Eduardo Spitti Resende for helping with the experiments.GRANTSThis work was supported by Fundação de Amparo a `Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo, Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico, and Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior.DISCLOSURESNo conflicts of interest, financial or otherwise, are declared by the author(s).AUTHORCONTRIBUTIONS R.L.M., A.M.H., B.V., M.T., N.A., and M.A.M. performed experiments; R.L.M., A.M.H., R.C.A., C.R.N., J.R.C., A.K.C., M.B., and J.B.P. analyzed data; R.L.M., R.C.A., C.R.N., J.R.C., A.K.C., M.B., and J.B.P. interpreted results of experiments; R.L.M., M.B., and J.B.P. prepared figures; R.L.M., M.B., and J.B.P. drafted manuscript; R.L.M., A.M.H., A.K.C., M.B., and J.B.P. edited and revised manuscript; R.L.M., A.M.H., B.V., M.T., N.A., M.A.M., R.C.A., C.R.N., J.R.C., A.K.C., M.B., and J.B.P. approved final version of manuscript.
